section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to count objects, sing a number song, and introduce vocabulary (creatures).
Begin Story Time by asking, How is this family like your family?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, stopping to count creatures on the page.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to 5 objects into two sets of any amount.
Focus Attention. Continue looking at, listening to, or thinking about something, even if there are interruptions or distractions.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review counting.
Teach children to subitize—say the number of dots on a card without counting.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book are you reading?
Are you pretending to be a family member? Which one?
How many are in this group?
Tell about what your family likes to do together.
Can you make your own dot cards?
How many letters are in your name?
What blocks are you building with? Why did you pick those?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to learn about working memory and introduce vocabulary (goal, humans).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Five Creatures.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to 5 objects into two sets of any amount.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Identify unique characteristics of families.
Verbally share the meaning of their own writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children cards with sets of 1–5 items.
Ask children to use their working memory to find two sets containing the same number of items.
Encourage children to subitize the images.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any humans in this book? Who are they?
Can you act like someone else in the pretend family?
If you add one more, how would that change the total?
Write about a goal you have.
I wonder why you chose those colors...
What letter do you hear at the beginning of goal?
Why did you use those materials to build that creature?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Five Creatures by Emily Jenkins, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2001 by Emily Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2001 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to learn measurement, play a game, and introduce vocabulary (short, long).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Five Creatures and asking the guiding question, Which activities do some of the creatures do together?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and a focus on measurement.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children find five long and short blocks.
Guide children to sort blocks by height and then build two towers.
Discuss how the order you count in does not affect the total.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is there a family in this book? Describe the creatures in the family.
Pretend to be a builder. How will you build a tall tower? a short tower?
Which tools can you use to decide how tall something is?
Write about how it would feel to be taller than your parents.
Can you draw two objects and make one taller than the other? Which is the short one?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of taller?
What is the longest thing you can build with those materials?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Five Creatures by Emily Jenkins, illustrated by Tomek Bogacki. Text copyright © 2001 by Emily Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2001 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Nenov Brothers Images/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: My Family and Me

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a family game, share different names for “grandmother,” and introduce vocabulary (grandparents, grandchild).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts My Family and Me and Five Creatures .
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question, What makes a family?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Counting: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.Counting: Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets or up to 5 objects into two sets of any amount.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to subitize the number of people on each card.
Guide children to count each member of the family.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you like about that book?
Pretend to be a creature. Why did you decide to act like that creature?
Show the number of creatures in your family.
What will you write first and why?
Draw all the creatures in your family. Which creature is the tallest? The shortest?
Can you look around the room and find letters from your name?
Make two towers and compare them. Which is the short tower?

Illustrations copyright © 2001 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Svitlana Kataieva/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to act out measurements, play a subitizing game, and review vocabulary (creatures).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book Five Creatures, and asking, What is something all the creatures in your family like to do that this family also does?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Use numerals 0–5 to represent a group of counted objects.
Identify measurable attributes like height, length, capacity, weight, and time.
Focus Attention. Continue looking at, listening to, or thinking about something, even if there are interruptions or distractions.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What do you love to do with your family?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Which creature in this story is most like you?
Why did you decide to pretend to be this creature? Tell me about it.
Which pile has more? How do you know?
Can you write a story that has five creatures in it?
Can you draw someone in your family? What can you add to the picture to show what he or she likes to do?
What sound does your name start with? Do you know what letter makes that sound?
Why did you build with those materials?

Illustrations copyright © 2001 by Tomek Bogacki. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Farrar, Straus and Giroux, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 items into equal groups.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher directed) tasks until completed.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 items into equal groups.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplishgoals.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher directed) tasks until completed.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.

Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 items into equal groups .
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplishgoals.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.

Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher directed) tasks until completed.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
